description.narrative: Over the past two years Mali has faced an open conflict in its northern region through the presence of multiple armed groups, the presence of French and UN forces, and the Malian military. While the impact of the conflict is most directly felt by communities living in the north, including those that have been displaced, the conflict has affected people living in the South. Hosting displaced family members, collective fear and shock, disrupted aid budgets, and increased reconstruction needs in the north are just some waysMalians throughout the country have been affected by the recent violent conflict. There are also localized conflicts throughout thecountry related to natural resources and agro-pastoral tensions over land. However, over the past two years much of the framing of conflict issues had tended to focus on the occupation of the north by armed groups and the presence of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Magreb (AQIM). A fuller understanding is required to understand the range of conflict issues affecting Mali and how Oxfam#s programming may address these issues. Oxfam in Mali#s governance programme includes a cross-cutting priority on conflict transformation and reconciliation. The programme also include a strategic direction on improving access to justice including for communities affected by violence in the north, and on improving women#s political participation through the framework of women, peace and security. Objectives Participatory conflict analysis and training in Mopti, Wednesday 02 July # Sunday 06 July, 2014. Build off the Tuareg-Peuhl dialogue in Bamako to further analyse causes, drivers of inter-communal violence and opportunities for peace. This will include examining specific conflicts between: nomadic communities (tuareg and peuhls) over land and water; between pastoral and agricultural communities; banditism. Develop a joint vision for causes of violence and opportunities for peace which can be undertaken directly by participants. Provide participants with experience, tools, ideas for undertaking similar dialogues with affected communities. Network different actors in the region working on related conflicts Participatory conflict analysis and training in Gao, Wednesday 09 July # Sunday 13 July, 2014. Inform staff on tools for conflict analysis and practice using tools Jointly analyze conflicts in Gao region with staff, partners, and invited organizations to inform the design and development for Oxfam#s reconciliation work in Gao. Outputs and Outcomes Conflict analysis #light# for Mopti and Gao regions # specific cercles and issues only Increased understanding and skills among staff and partner to undertake conflict analysis Common understanding on options for conflict transformation and reconciliationprogramming among partners Action Plans and integration of CT into programme strategies or project implementation plans. A common vision to working with conflicts shared by Oxfam in Mali staff involved in governance, reconciliation, protection, and social cohesion.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam is an international confederation of 17 organizations working together in more than 90 countries. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name "Oxfam" comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War.As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 17 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada,France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Brussels, Geneva, New York, Washington DC and Brasilia. Oxfam GB is an actor in the implementation of this project.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: no. of cases that show how partner organisations use new tools to measure and improve the legitimacy and risk management of organisations, with a special focus on (women) organisations in countries with repression and conflict.
